title: (x) "Joseph L. Baird Radd K. Ehrman" very elegant sharp serif face - Folkwang {Carl}
content:
I ran across this very elegant font and was wondering what it is called. I have looked online without any success. Can anyone help?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905062520im_/http:/typophile.com/files/jos_5572.gif)

 [‹ (x) Serif face used for Richard Quay's online resume - Foundry Wilson {Yves}](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905062520/http:/typophile.com/node/47790 "Go to previous forum topic") [Any ideas about this font? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905062520/http:/typophile.com/node/47827 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Tonie Blaze

comments.content:
Tonie

This looks so familiar. I went through Lindegren’s book and cannot find it. I will keep looking.

Michael

Thanks. I appreciate the help. I know what you mean...it looks really familiar, but I am getting to the point where I believe I am hallucinating (or just confusing it with other fonts - yeah, we’ll go with that!)

It is very calligraphic and I think it has a Scandinavian, and or German, feel to it but I have been off the mark many times before.

I am really interested in finding this one. I am still looking, it has a Lindegren, Forsberg or Gudrun Zapf (I know it is not her) feel to it. Check out Diotima Italic by Gudrun Zapf and you will see what I mean.

Michael

M. Yanega see 47447!

Hopefully this will get your attention. Got any ideas on this one?????

Michael
Is that the name of the face, Carl?
I was rushing: Folkwang is the face. The info I found said it was from 1949 from Klingspor, but I didn’t check that info.

Thank you, thank you, thank you Carl!!!!!!

As soon as I saw Folkwang it clicked. I had already been through my Stemple catalogues and was getting around to researching Klingspor.

Yay... I can sleep now.

Michael

Available digitally from Phil’s Fonts as [Wicked](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905062520/http:/www.philsfonts.com/sresults.html?key=adv&wrd=wa&rslts=20&famsrch=T&keyword=wicked&submit.x=9&submit.y=9).
